description:
In a sea of Mexican restaurants, it's nice to grab some Nicaraguan food.  Doesn't seem gentrified like other restaurants nearby, though it will be a bit pricier than tacos or burritos.  However, that must be because you get enough food for two meals.  And it's not because I had a weak appetite or anything, literally every other table was taking leftovers home.

Antojitos "Las Tinajas": Not sure why it's called antojitos, since it's more like a massive double meal plate than an appetizer or snack.  If you can't decide which grilled meat to get, this combo is a great option.  Skirt steak that is heavily marinated and charbroiled, delicious in each bite.  Also, another heavily spiced large cut of pork that is pounded thin and grilled with nice grill marks.  The fact that this platter came with a big chunk of fried cheese seal the deal, so yummy.  The rice mixed with beans were a nice hearty side.  More fried plantain chips than I knew what to do with.  Also some softer and sweeter maduros, that helped contrast the salty umami of everything else.  The pickled onions went really well with the meats.
 
Pitaya Juice: Sweeter than fresh red dragon fruit, maybe they added a little sugar?  Quite refreshing.
author: Adam B.

description: This place is never a disappointment.  The food here is delicious and portions big enough to save a little for later. Had the Nica Plate this time around and so much flavor on the steak and pork, washed it down with Cacao.
author: Alex R.

description: It is really unfortunate that I'm writing this review for Las Tinajas.  This restaurant was QUITE a disappointment. After going here 30+ years The food is now an embarrassment. I went to lunch with HIGH expectations I took a friend with me, so they can get the Nicaraguan experience in FLAVOR in food. Once there hardly any food, trays were empty (this was 1PM) the ladies were cleaning up, seems as if they were getting ready to close, only a couple of tables with customers.  I ordered Vigoron,(not much from the menu was available)  the chicarron was hard as a rock, separately ordered steak dinner, order of fried cheese and platano verde (which I didn't get), instead I got quesadilla (I didn't order), 1 water and 1 cacao,1 cold bunuello and the owner charged $65.00. I asked why so much. The owner just looked at me as If I was crazy. The food was NOT great, it was not what I was expecting, even the traditional gallo pinto on the steak plate - no flavor and cold. I even tried to return an order that I didn't ask for - but he owner charge me.  I even asked one of the ladies that works there, what has happened to this place, it used to be "The Place to go for Nicarguan food". The lady replied " it's not the same, people change".  It is unfortunate that I could not have my friend experience the traditional food from my county, and to point out...I WILL NOT RETURN. The price is not a big deal, if I would have received what I ordered.   This used to be the place that my family would go frequently.  Not anymore.
author: Li R.

description:
A gal at work recommended this place.  It is certainly authentic full of only Spanish speaking folks (customers and workers)

We ordered the plate of the day with includes pork, some fried cheese, plantains (two ways crispy and braised), and rice mixed with beans, and a coleslaw salad. It was a TON of food. we also got one of the triangular pastry above the hot line.

And we split a cocoa drink (down by the register) - very good, not quite chocolate milk, but in the neighborhood.

The cheese was my favorite, my hubby said the pork.  It was good, and I am happy to have tried it, but maybe Nicaraguan food just isn't my thing.

VERY clean place - even the bathrooms
author: Amy W.

description: Best Nicaragüense food ever! The gallo pinto, queso frito, maduro, pasteles de pollo, man I can go on forever and ever! Get your butts in here and try one of everything!
author: Laura M.

description: Dropped in here for a small inexpensive meal of a nacatamal or Nicaraguan tamale.  It wasn't quick; they told me it'd take 20 minutes, but it was fresh and pretty good, with the meat broken up and with all the other unusual fillings that go in one of these.
author: David B.

description: Delicious! Wife is from Nicaragua and was happy I found this spot while we were in town. I ordered carne asada and her something with mincemeat. Both entrees were excellent! We took some baked goods to go and would love to come back when down in the Bay Area again.
author: John R.

description: Not many Nicaraguan restaurants in SF like Miami " that being said this place is solid and the nacatamales are very good! And anybody who is Nicaraguan can appreciate that. No Flor De Cana though
author: Sean K.

description: Worst customer service! Salad tasted past due with a strong bad taste. Eduardo was rude and impotent to help with my experience. Server opened my salad put his fingers inside and said it tasted fine. Wtf!! As an employee who the fuck puts there hands inside any food while they're working! Use to be my fav place! Now I'm very disappointed to inform the public of how disgusting and unsanitary this place is! Worst of all they did not refund or replace the item with something else besides the point that i drove all the way back from my house! Very disappointed!
author: Rafaela R.

description:
We have been coming here for years. The food is good usually. 

However in the recent years the customer service is lacking and I don't wish to give them the business. 

We ordered the carne Asada platter and we finished all of our food and were still waiting for the carne asada platter and it still had not been served. 

When we asked why it took so long they said oh because. 

Very rude and very unappreciative since I've contributed to their restaurant for so many years!!!!
author: Marissa C.

description:
Visited SF for a few days (this vacation was our first). Although I knew we planned on visiting the Mission District- I've already "bookmarked" a few places to eat. However, my cousin recommended Las Tinajas- since her bf grew up eating here. How could I pass up the recommendation? We went on a Tuesday. I ordered the Antojitos "Las Tinajas", a Caldo de Res (soup), & Pio Quinto (Rum Cake w/ custard). Horchata to drink. My husband ordered the Carne Asada Estilo Nica.
The prices are very well worth what you're getting. Plates are full of food. I could've taken leftovers back to the hotel- but, chose not too. Basically, we could've shared a plate between us!
author: Joanne P.

description: too expansive! $20 for each fast food meal. Tasted like Filipino food with more dollar signs, not worth the bucks, just a fast food lunch, cost too much.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
I wonder if the good reviews are nostalgia-driven. I have eaten here a few times, always in a group. I will smile and laugh but I secretly hope everyone is enjoying their meal and not secretly underwhelmed liked me. 

It is cafeteria style, they serve a lot of food (bang for your buck). But it is pretty middle of the road in terms of flavor. Most of the food is in warming plates so it can get pretty dry. Fried plantains and fried cheese are always good (but that goes without saying). Get there closer to lunchtime if you would like the special or if you are in the mood for steak, it may be busier but they sell out of their entrees (and that's it... all done)

If you can make gallo pinto, ensalada, tajadas con queso, etc at home, then you will not likely be impressed. But if this is your spot and you love it. Don't be mad, just do you.
author: Andrew L.

description: My dad is Nicaraguan and this was my first time ever trying a few things. So glad I finally got to try, it was delicious!
author: A.J S.

description:
Eat what the Sandinistas eat!!

You might think of Central America as small place where all the countries are right next to each other and share identical cuisines! Well in reality this is not the case! As you go from north to south through Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama the cuisines change a great deal, but many of the popular basic ingredients like Rice, Beans, plantains, corn, etc. carry through. However, here in the Bay Area we mostly see what North American eaters have a taste for, hence lots of rice, beans, pork, beef, etc in Central American restaurant dishes. Las Tinajas Restaurant is not different in that sense.

Las Tinajas is a cafeteria style eatery. It has a clean eating area, and the servers behind the counter are very nice and fast (depending of course on what you order). I liked the rice and bean mix, but you can also ask for them separately. The fried cheese was something different for me and I really liked it, but quickly learned that you must eat it while it is still very warm, or it will taste like  like leather! The pork was very good, so was the beef, but what I loved most was the flan which I had as dessert!

Judging from the crowd and the line, Las Tinajas is a popular spot, and that's a good thing! To be honest I know nothing about the owners, but if they are the people who run the kitchen and the floor, it must be a family owned business. 

Next time I am there, I will try a couple of the filling soups they serve. Hmm! Hungry again already!
author: Afshin A.

description:
I came here with a friwns for a late lunch, probably around 3:30 pm. We had lengua and carne asada, and as always it was delicious. 
However, at around 4:15 pm, a man starts to vacuum, and we are still eating and enjoying our conversation and dessert. Amazingly,  he starts pulling out the chairs from oyr table, and asked him to please stop vacuuming around us, and he doesn't respond...just like we were invisible to him.
My friend was upset.
author: Kay H.

description:
First time trying this spot out as it always closes early or is closed when I pass by.  They say they're open until 4:30 but that's not true as I saw the lady flip the sign to 'closed' St 4pm.  Glad I came earlier, otherwise I would've gotten the closed sign. 

I've heard many good things about the place.  I ordered the Antojitos Las Tinajas combo plate which consists of Gallo pinto, banana chips, shredded cabbage salad, carne asada, pork, plantains, and queso Frito.  It was all very good but I was a bit disappointed in the meat, it wasn't exactly as tender as I expected, but I did come at the end of the day so not surprised and won't hold it against them.

Will try coming here earlier and eat inside.  Overall, they're pretty good.  I'm coming back!
author: Jill P.

description: 2 stars means good food , awful customer service . Like most Latin American places I go to at least here in California and Nicaragua ,  they suck in customer service and they can't be consistent . I mean , get a clue guys , there's only a few of great Latin American restaurants in the bay , and the reason they are successful is because they make damn sure they bring , great customer service , and are consistent with their plates . And I'm Nicaraguan , I know my people in Nicaragua suck when it comes to customer service but in Nicaragua at least they are consistent , their food is always on point .m, and is so cheap , that I can put with the customer service .
author: Ardi B.

description: This is a great restaurant offering authentic Nicaraguan food. This is one of only a handful of restaurants that tastes like the homemade meals I have had both here in the states, and Nicaragua.
author: Hadassah W.

description: This place is amazing. The meat paired with the rice and fries is a great combo. 10/10 I highly recommend if you're in SF! Great steak and big portions
author: Christopher K.

description: I love this place, the only Nicaraguan restaurant that I go, I love the ambient, the only thing bad about it is that they close early and they don't open on Sunday, I would love a carne asada on a Sunday afternoon hahah  The cacao is amazing and the quesillos are delicious. 100% recommended if you are looking for a 100% real Nicaraguan food
author: Douglas J.

description: One of my favorite Nicoya restaurants. Recommend el antojito with un fresco de cacao. No matter what you order, you can't go wrong.
author: Maria C.

description:
Hygiene issues.
About two weeks ago, I ordered a large Pitaya drink that tasted a bit like lemon only. I hesitated to ask for a replacement as I know how it goes with some nicaraguan folks who run business. I did anyways, only to get disappointed:

Me: the pitaya doesn't taste like pitaya, i can only taste a tiny bit of lemon, can it be replaced with a different drink?

Lady grabs a small cup and pour some pitaya in it from the jar and tasted the drink
Lady: it does taste like pitaya. 
Then she asked a customer who was in the line ready to pay for his food to taste the drink for her to reassure me , using the same cup she just used. The customer told her that he doesn't really taste foods due to some sort of problem he has. Then she turns to one of the workers and asked to taste it for her, again, from the same cup she just used. All this time i am watching the show as I am in shock! Really? You are willing to lose a long time customer for a few bucks?! And not only that, hygiene concerns. Only God knows what happens in the kitchen, who taste the food/drinks to prove (all from the same cup/spoon, sharing saliva!) how good/bad it is, gross. 
Well, the worker agrees with her and says "it is good, and that's how the fruit taste like".

Lady: I can't change it, sorry, it is your taste.

Me: ok, thank you, don't worry about it.

Very disappointed. I hope the owner reads this review and execute a plan if she/he cares. Otherwise, someone could get sick if these are the practices of handling food there.

I would have returned if it was just for $ issue but i wouldn't be able to eat/drink anything there anymore. 

I do have to say, one of the waitress tried changing the drink for me after the fact, as she felt bad, but was not successful. She apologized in a very humble way but I told her not to worry about it.

Be careful if you still decide to try the food from here.
author: Hei A.

description: Yes, genuine Nicaraguan food and in large quantities. Very casual cafeteria style but staff will check in to make sure you have what you need. This is a lunch place, not open evenings or Sundays.
author: Susangela M.

description:
It doesn't get more authentic than Tinajas.  It feels like  take out the but the food is stellar!  Very good portions and as many possible authentic dishes as possible.  Right down to the drinks!   I was told the Catamales were done the night before and ready to taste!

Always a good visit every time I'm in town.  Bring your Spanish and get some good laughs from the waitress.
author: David Y.

description: I love this place. The gallop into is on point and I love the fritanga (vegetarian plate) which I get with both types of plantains. I especially like the onions and carrot chile on the table. It's delicious on top of the salad. My favorite Nicaraguan food, by far.
author: Nancy R.

description:
I first went to this spot 13 years ago and hadn't been back since - I just went back and really enjoyed my meal.  I got Combination Plate #1, which had grilled beef, grilled pork, rice/beans, plantains, fresh slaw, fried cheese and plantain chips - a huge plate of maybe 2 lbs. of food.  Everything tasted great and had amazing flavor.  I also ordered the Horchata, which was a nice and unique Nicaraguan version of the popular dish.  

While the food was great, I wasn't too thrilled with the cafeteria experience...I guess it just makes sense to arrive early or later during lunch time since the line can be long, but there's no guarantee you'll get a seat.

When Nicagragua Restaurant closed, I was hoping this place would be a good alternative and it is...I really enjoyed my meal...one just has to be prepared with possible long lines and be mindful of seating options.
author: Ken G.

description: Recommended by my Nicaraguan co-worker. Great food, cooked with lots of love! The Baho was on point and very filling. The beef was tender and easy to eat. The plantains kinda missed the mark for me, but the yuca root tasted great - like a firm potato. The borrachitos for dessert had quite a kick - as a rum dish should! The restaurant is cafeteria-style but the waitresses take your tray and seat you. The prices are kinda steep but for a specialty food that's to be expected.
author: Tony B.

description: O.M.G! This place was like eating at my grandma's house. They had every dish that my grandma made for me when I was little. Delicious! I had the Nica Special! Soo yummy! The portions here are super generous! This comfort food made want to fall alseep with a blanket! Flawless dish! Piece of advice only get a small size of cacao with your food.
author: Kyle W.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city coming from a person who lived here for 21 years of my life. I haven't tried every dish but I only stick to two dishes: the chuleta de pesacdo or the carne asada. It is sooooo good and every time it taste perfect.
author: Justin W.

description: Tasty food, large quantities, and a clean spacious setting. The service was a little off as they missed half our order initially but  were quick in recovering. Would try this place again if in the area.
author: E. Y. G.

description: Everytime we're in the city we tend to make a stop for some good food! Came here place an order to go...to have wasted $70 on lunch and for some Nacatamales that tasted nasty! The masa was gross! It was bland with a greasy taste! The cancho plate had only 3 little pieces...it was very disappointing! The only good thing was the cacao and the chia! There a rip off! Next time I will stay going to Oye Managua where you get more for your money and the food is good!
author: Rachell M.

description: I'll start off with saying I grew up eating here. My parents are both Nicaraguan and I grew up eating only authentic food. What I love about this place is that the portions are huge! You have to come in early, coming in at 12 or later on a Saturday is a horrible idea because the line goes out the door on the sidewalk... they are not open Sundays. Personally I think Wednesday's is a good day to come! They have traditional Nicaraguan dishes and treats!! something that sucks is they don't have the same dishes everyday... they have different specials of the day. Besides that this place is HELLA good. Oh by the way as you already know the city sucks for parking especially Mission street, good luck finding parking on the weekend!
author: Cupcake 1.

description: I would give this restaurant a 5 star but just were it's at in San Francisco is a really bad area and it's a tiny restaurant but the food and service is excellent. We love it.
author: Debra A.

description: The food was good the prize is a little bit pricey but is way better than the other places around here plus is worth it because they serve u a lot of food
author: Carlos V.

description: Best Nicaraguan food, love the cafeteria setup.. the people that work there are hard worker and nice
author: Selina A.

description: Anytime I'm in San Francisco, this place is a must.  It had been a while since my last visit. Today I walked in to enjoy a great meal but to my surprise things have gone down hill.  Food is still good, however, all the food was either cold old lukewarm. The kid at the register  was being trained and he was a bit rude. I hope they teach him a bit about customer service. I will say, on my next SF trip, I won't go out of my way to come here. I would like to see management look into serving hot food and not lukewarm or cold Yucca.  Thanks for the many years of great meals and see you .............  well...... I won't see you but good luck.
author: Will G.

description:
Pretty good food, but I don't enjoy the cafateria-style food service. The menu is lacking some of the best dishes you'd expect in Nicaragua. No soup? No stew? No seafood? WTH? I'd rather go a few blocks down to Oye Managua for more variety.

The menu is not really clear, and I think you pay extra for addons for basic stuff like gallo pinto and tejadas. By the time we paid, it was $100 for me, my husband and two kids!! Crazy! For that price, I'd like the food to "take me back" to Nicaragua, but it doesn't.
author: Amy P.

description:
I have been to every Nicaraguan restaurant in the Mission District and Las Tinajas is by far, the BEST NICARAGUAN restaurant in the Mission.

I'm married to a Nicaraguan and yes, this place is like eating a traditional Nacaraguan home cooked meal. 

I recommend you get the Carne Asada plate!
author: Teresa Q.

description:
Food is good but the lack of service is really low. We had this lady who brought one of our plates to our table who had the worse Negative Vibe.. Complaining to us that she couldn't wait to be off from work 'cause she had to go to her 2nd job... Boohoo! Lady, we all work! 
Oh, and the owners are rude & not happy to have your business. No greeting what so ever! Is this a Nicaraguan thing? Cause I was raised better then this...
author: Sary O.

description:
My dad is from Nicaragua, and we visit Nicaragua frequently enough to know what good Nicaraguan food tastes likes.  My family actually stopped coming here, mostly we felt it was overpriced for the type of food being served.  Items likes gallo pinto, queso frito, maduros, ensalada shouldn't be SO expensive. 

Anyway, about a month ago, stopped by for an early lunch while my car was getting serviced in the neighborhood and had the chancho frito plate (my favorite when I go to the motherland) and a cacao.  The cacao is on point, but how can you mess that up.  The chancho had good flavor and was a good portion, but my disappointment lay with the gallo pinto.  It was way to mushy for my liking, the rice and beans shouldn't form a mass.  I later mentioned this to my dad and he said that was one of the reasons he started frequenting other Nicaraguan restaurants.  The queso frito and maduro had a consistency of having been sitting around for a while, it was warm at best.  To say the least, $20 later I was disappointed.  

I remember being very little and the food being way above average, and if it were still like that i would have no problem shelling out $$ for delicious food, but it's not the case.  So, I guess this is where Las Tinajas and I part ways.
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
Deeeelicious! I had the braised tongue with white rice and black beans on the side.
The spicy sauces served on the side with it is super spicy and really well-balanced.. Great service, clean clean clean. Hot food hot. My first experience with Nicaraguan food. Will definitely come back!
author: jelly d.

description: Nice food with authentic feel.  Had the carne asada which tasted great.  Next time would get it with the tomato and onion sauce (that the prawns are cooked in).  Could also do with less rice (which tasted buttered).
author: Amit P.

description: I'm a proud Nicaraguan.. I took my best buddy who is Turkish!! He's turned me on to all of his food and now my turn to turn him on to Our wonderful Nicaraguan cooking!! He had the shredded beef!! Sissy!! Lol I had the Beef tongue aka Lengua con salsa!! It was amazing!! All my Tia's that lived in San Francisco are now all gone.. I really miss there cooking.  It was that good!! So I come to this place when I can get into town!! I'm a original San Franciscan that had to move out !! LOL.. we also had fried cheese, and fried rip plaintins!! OMG I was in love!! My buddy live his food so much he went back for Rice pudding he saw on his way in.. He had to get it and compare it to his Turkish style he loves so much!! Well I called him later and he was in heaven and said it was the best he ever had!! Lol .. that's right fool!! I told him our cuisine was amazing!! That's why all the Latinos MLB players always eat there. All the Latinos playing for the giants can be spotted when in town!! Yes I have seen them plenty of times.. that's how good it is here!  People try it you'll like it, and try the Salpicon !! It's great!  Everything is great!! Peace be with you all!!
author: Mauricio G.

description:
It's hard to find Nicaraguan food.  I mean good Nicaraguan food and Las Tinajas has the reputation of being one of the best in SF.  Unfortunately, it doesn't say much about the quality of Nica cuisine in the City.
This place is only open banker's hours closing by 4:30 PM.  So you have to come by for lunch during the week.  The menu can be limited but every dish averages about $15.  Pretty pricey for cafeteria tray service.
Where Las Tinajas lets down is culinary authenticity.  They ran out of gallo pinto at my last visit.  I asked why they couldn't make more.  They said they would have to ask the kitchen ???  The lady came back and said it would be five minutes.  10 minutes later I was served pot pinto beans mixed with rice.  What a let down.  When I told them gallo pinto are small red beans, they just smiled at each other.  The fried cheese was leather tough and the maduros were stale.
I wouldn't call this the best example of Nicaraguan food.  Will eat elsewhere next time I get the craving of my home food.
Parking can be tough on nearby streets
author: Pablo R.

description:
I am Native to the Mission District and I have roots in Nicaragua. This being one of a handful of Nicaraguense restaurants in San Francisco, I have been a quite a few times. My most recent visit might be my last. Went for lunch on a Friday afternoon, attempted to order the fried fish when they told me it would be over 30 minutes to make, the I attempted to order soup, not available. Then I attempted to order a raspado, not available. Their drinks are not fresh and very sweet. 

The service is atrocious. I was was left in awe. I would rather buy the food and have my grandmother cook than to step back in this place. I asked for more napkins and they asked why? REALLY???

The food, well it was decent but the cleanliness and service is terrible. Oh did I mention on a previous visit my guest found a cockroach in his food, they simply removed it, no compensation given to the bill. Ah yes, and their prices are very expensive!

I suggest trying the other Nicaraguense places
author: Ed S.

description:
My family and I had fried plantains, queso frito, ensalada, and Gallo pinto. Pretty good for $10 each, however I didn't like that we couldn't order from a table. It was a cafeteria-like setting - it wouldn't have bothered me so much but I felt like I was being rushed to order something on the spot, instead of chilling at the table with family and taking our time to order from the menu.

That said, the food was delicious and based on a previous experience from a rival Nicaraguan restaurant in San Francisco, I'd rather go here for the more reasonable prices.
author: Erica R.

description: This is by far the Best Nicaraguan/Nicaraguense Restaurant in the Bay Area.  Everything they serve is authentic, and with that Unique taste to every dish they serve.  My son and i are regular customers and I recommend it to everytone.  Two of my favorite dishes are Lengua Entomatada, and Bajo. So if you are looking for the best Nacaraguense Restaurant in town, there you have it.  Enjoy! :)
author: Denis R.

description:
Cafeteria style restaurant. 

This is the only Nicaraguan restaurant in San Francisco where you might not get the tacky treatment. Very decent food--Nicaraguan, with a slight Chinese twist. 

Their cleanliness level varies throughout the years: I found a cockroach in my gallo pinto about ten years ago, but I totally forgive them because of their consistent efforts throughout many years in keeping their restaurant decently organized.

Overpriced. Table cloths dirty. Closes too early. Generally, quiet family atmosphere, which is totally unusual in the iffy neighborhood.
author: Raymond F.

description:
These people are super rude.  I takes an act of Congress for them to say thank you.
Even though the food is top-notch, I won't eat there anymore.  One star for the attitude of the owners and 5 stars for the food.
author: Andre T.

description:
If I could give this place zero stars, I would. Now I used to come here growing up which is 15+ years, and my experience today was hands down the worst and not the Tinajas I remember. I came here a year ago with my mom and the food was ehhhh not the usual and today the food was disgusting. We only ate it because we were so hungry and the restaurant we originally wanted to eat at was closed and Las Tinajas was nearby. I ordered the vegetarian plate and my company ordered two Plato Tipico's and my boyfriend grilled chicken, he had to wait for his food. So all of our plates had stale platano maduros, and the other two had fried pork that was straight fat that it was inedible. And the best part which is the fried cheese, was soooo hard and dry and very disappointing. Maybe the plantains and cheese are days old because it definitely isn't fresh. 
Then the boyfriends plate came, when he ordered he was asked if he wanted rice or rice and beans and he asked for rice and beans. His plate comes with white rice and when he asked to change it, the lady said ok. She returns and said its an extra charge which was ok with him. He gets up. Goes to the register and pays extra. Smh. It's not about the money but good customer service would have just changed it. He is too served stale and dry plantains and his chicken was dry and charred. 
Also the buffet style line makes your food cold as you wait to pay and order drinks. 
So to sum it all up. Overpriced, days old food with HORRIBLE customer service. Save your money and go elsewhere. Now I need to find another Nicaraguan restaurant.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Sincerely the best Nicaraguan restaurant in the Bay Area. I have yet to be disappointed on a dish. The prices are a little up there, that would be my only con.
author: Roxanne A.

description: Food is delicious. I am not from Nicaragua but it tastes like authentic Central American food. The #1 antojitos plate can serve 2 people unless you're absolutely starving. Highly recommend
author: Rudy K.

description: So far so good. Haven't eaten yet but they have everything I want. Went to our spot, Oy Managua, but they didn't have Toña or nacatamales. Disappointed. Here the Toñas are a dollar cheaper and the nacatamales are $1.50 cheaper. Found a new spot I think.
author: Brian V.

description: Service suck, server's face scares you once you step in the door. I called before a go and they told me they closed At 4:30 got there at 3:50 and as soon as I walked in the told me they were closed, after I looked for parking and just waited my time. They were pretty rude and did not even apologize for the confusion. If you don't have the passion for what you than don't work stay home. Is not my fault... Never will go back there again. And the only reason I give one start is because I have too lol
author: Marcela M.

description:
I love Las Tinajas! I wish they had a Nicaraguan restaurant like this in the East Bay. I love to get their Plato Vegetariano which comes with queso frito, platano maduro, gallo pinto, and cabbage. YUM!

Also the Cacao is a MUST! So good!
author: Mario M.

description:
Food is decent. I usually get the basics, tajadas con queso frito y ensalada. You can't go wrong with that. 

However the Baho sucks! It is like steamed dry meat. Baho usually is so tender and delicious. This one was awful. 

The beans are good but these are not Nicaraguan beans. So I think that to sell Nicaraguan style beans they should be real Nicaraguan beans. These are too big. 

Rice is steamed....enough said there. Nicaraguan rice is fluffy and fried. I get that the other is probably healthier but it isn't Nicaraguan style at all. 

The raspados are over rates, yuck. I was so excited, I drove 60 miles to go but was very disappointed. 

The quesillo is pretty good, but just one tortilla is not enough. For $5 they should have two tortillas. 

So overall I would say they are ok
author: Vera M.

description: Most authentic Nicaraguan restaurant you'll find in SF. My family and I almost couldn't walk we were so full with food and joy from eating here. Us nicoya's were happy and full :)
author: Sara J.

description: Been here twice & they never dissapointed us! Nicaraguan steak, queso frito, plaintains + banana chips = perfect combo! Yes, gotta have their cacao when u are in a Nicaraguan restaurant. It's pricey but hey they served very good food. Whhen u get good food, don't expect it to be cheap! Piece of advice ~ if u want to pay a cheap price then expect to get a cheap food, just saying!
author: Bhonz Z.

description:
This is my favorite Nicaraguense restaurant, hands down. Simple, fresh, and delicious. I usually get the gallo pinto with queso frito and a fresco de cacao to drink. The gallo pinto tastes just like my grandma's and the fresco de cacao is very filling with just the right amount of sweetness. 

Las Tinajas also has Nicaraguense pastries and empanadas which are just as good. Their picos (sweet cheese pastry) are really good. I also recommend their pasteles de pollo (chicken pies/empanadas). The crust of the pasteles de pollo have sugar on them, which might seem odd for a savory pie, but it's actually quite good.
author: Elena L.

description: I like deeply ethnic and indigenous flavor. One of the best places I have ever eaten for latin food. On par with some of the best places I've been to in Mexico.
author: Jason T.

description: Food was alright, overrated & overpriced! Carpets are filthy, and Gallo pinto was not fresh! Fried plantains were stale as well! I don't think I'll be back!
author: Robin O.

description: Best Nicoya place in SF. Great service and if you love Carne Desilachada go on a Thursday! They have different daily plates.
author: Mina S.

description: I've been coming here for years! I take everyone I know down here and let them know this Nicaraguense food is a MUST on their trip to SF. If you want some delicious Latin food come here! It's a cozy place with such kind staff. Everyone here is welcoming and kind! The food tastes DELICIOUS.
author: Ari V.

description:
Seeing the Yelp reviews and considering I had never had Nicaraguan food incentivized me to go here. I dragged my friend along who is willing to eat anything. When we showed up the nice lady behind the cafeteria stand asked what we wanted to eat. In Spanish. My friend and I ordered the special by pointing to it and she understood. At least, I think she understood.

Anyways, one special came out and it was HUGE. It was $14 and featured steak, fried cheese, plantain fries, rice, and some coleslaw. Oh god, I detest eating meat (despite not begin a vegetarian), but I was a complete dinosaur for this well-seasoned, perfectly juicy steak. Seriously, this meat is so good that I was enjoying a steak for the first time in years. I felt like a complete dinosaur during that meal. One special dish is enough for two, I just need to remember to drag a Spanish-speaking friend to help me order next time.
author: Tony H.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and decided to try this place for lunch. I was a little surprised by the menu prices but thought I'd give it a shot anyways. 

I ended up trying the lunch special which was shredded beef with rice and choice of salad or beans. The shredded beef was tasty but there was nothing special about the rest of the plate. The rice was bland though a fine complement to the shredded beef. The salad was basically some packaged lettuce with dressing drizzled on. Overall, I felt lunch was overpriced given the quality of food. Quantity was fine.

The place felt dated. The staff wasn't that friendly. It didn't help that you had to line up cafeteria style to get your food. The difference between lunch and dinner service may be night and day so I may give it another shot to try what other yelps are raving about, but I likely wouldn't come back for lunch given the plentiful options in the neighborhood.
author: Victor W.

description: As a nicoya this has been a staple for my family forever. The carne asada is expensive plate but only my momma makes a better one than theirs on the grill. And if my mom likes their carne asada anyone who knows us knows its LEGIT!!! they pile on so much food its like you are in nicaragua. This is the only good nicaraguan spot in the bay...period.
author: Karla C.

description:
I ordered the carne asada plate with rice, salad, fried plantains, it was very nicely prepared and the meat was  a small grilled beef steak , everything tasted very good, it was around $17

this place gets pretty busy on a Saturday afternoon, I can tell it was a good restaurant by the crowd

I forgot to order the cacao drink, I heard it was also highly recommended.

the service was very fast and they were very friendly when I asked about the dishes, excellent service.

I always wanted to try Nicaraguan cuisine, I would definitely come back again!
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: Great Nicaraguan food.  Having lived in Nicaragua for two years, I've looked high and low for good Nica food.  I've tried a few places in the Mission and this is definitely one of the best.  It's fresh and simple.  The portions are huge, but somewhat pricier than I would expect.  I also really liked their fresco de cacao and they have Tonas (Nicaraguan beer)!
author: Stephanie L.

description: Where my love of Nicoya food started. Order cacao its a must I describe it like a chocolatey horchata but much better.
author: Yoselin M.

description:
I don't have anything bad to say about this place besides that I always spend about $90 for a party of 3 when I go. The menu is amazing and authentic Nicarguan to be exact. I love the carne asada dish with the beans and rice, fried plantains and cheese. 
Yes, they serve fried cheese! It is amazing as weird as it sounds. 

I also LOVE the flan. I am prety sure they have the best flan ever. Staff is also very nice and friendly despite some of them only speaking Spanish. I recommend this place to those who want a taste of authentic Latin food.
author: Alex U.

description: Been here many times! It's the BEST Nicaraguan restaurant in the bayarea!!!the food is always delicious and fresh, portions are pretty big and they have a large selection. I always get the "antojito" which brings carne asada, grilled pork, rica and beans( Gallo pinto), sweet plantains( maduros),fried cheese and cabbage salad. The only bad thing about this place is its hours and customer service.
author: Karen H.

description: Only reason to come here is because your out of town friends want Nicoya food, and there's no other place for good Nica food. That being said, the food is pretty bland. I'm not a cook but I even do a better job than this, except for the empanadas, stuffed pies, are pretty good. That's the only thing worth eating and for drinks the cacao. But then,of course, I'm a picky eater, so if you like it, then go for it.
author: Petra M.

description:
WOW!!!! Very, Very, Very EXPENSIVE
Ridiculous...
I love my Nicaraguense food but this places Exsagerate with there $$$$$$$. The worse thing about this particular place is that they have there food like a buffet & they are the ones who served the food for you, so you know what that means? Rite! they give you so very little of food like a child?????? I just decided to cook on my own & with a little $$$ I can cook for my whole family.
author: Patricia F.

description: This is by far my favorite place to come and eat to when I am in San Francisco! The food here is fresh, the service is great, and the atmosphere is nice too. I ordered the carne asada plate which was about 17$, a little pricy, but well worth it. It was a lot of food, and I even had some leftovers for dinner! I recommend anyone in the area to stop by because you will not regret it!
author: LisaMarie M.

description:
Probably the best steak I've eaten in a restaurant.  My recommendation is to order the carne asada plate (not a traditional thin steak like in Mexico, but instead a thick char-grilled piece of meat cooked to perfection), which is served with a generous helping of rice, black beans (combined in one if you prefer) with your choice of two types of plantains (crispy or sauteed).  At your table, you'll enjoy a Nicaraguan Chimi-churri like sauce (but with a water base vs an oil base) and vinegar-lime marinated onions - Yum!

This place is not cheap with this plate priced around $15, but it is worth every bite!  Unique selection of drinks at the front as well - would certainly recommend experimenting and trying some out.  

Keep in mind however that this place is cafeteria style and is not a place where the ambiance will impress anyone.  They speak very little English and close after lunchtime.  Other than that, I highly recommend this place if you're in the mood for good food!!
author: Michael M.

description: Large quantities and tasty food. You'll go into a food coma once you get done with your food. This is as close as authentic you'll get to Nicaraguan food and as a native Nicaraguan, I think Las Tinajas is better and "healthier". When my family and I come to eat here we make sure we plan ahead since we live far from it. We buy every plate we can fit in our bags :) The trip is always worth it. The service is good since the waiters already know us just plan around it since the inside of the place is small and is always busy.
author: Valeria B.

description: First time ever trying Nicaraguan food I got the antojitos plate and it was delicious the queso frito, platanos,tostones and the two choices of meat  were an excellent combo...Will definitely be back
author: Mike E.

description: Great food. Really big space with huge glass windows. People are nice and assume you speak Spanish which is kind of cool. Honestly don't remember exactly what I got but I think it was the plate with carne asada and chicken which was delicious. The flan was pretty good though not amazing.
author: Tony P.

description: I was so turned off with the price of two entrees, a side of plantains, two sides of sour cream, and two horchatas. It came out to $55!!! However the food was amazing and the portions were huge. I'm not a fan of the plantain chips - either they were stale or the texture just isn't my thing. The food was delicious though and if somebody invited me there for lunch, I def wouldn't turn the invite down. I would have given 5 stars but it's soooooooooo expensive
author: Courtney A.

description: Best nicaraguan food in the bay area hands down.  Wish the place didn't feel like a high school lunch room but,  im here to grub and then do have some great dishes.  I take the # 1 i don't get pork so they just give me more meat.
author: Joe B.

description: Been a long time customer (at least 15+) and the food is STILL delicious. I get the Baho which is only available tues., fri., and sat. Nicaraguan food at its finest. Definitely recommend if you are a beginner or expert latin food lover! Don't forget to add a side of horchata which is so refreshing!! My father absolutely loves the beef soup and he's as white as it gets lol! 5 STARS!
author: Stacey B.

description: One of the best haspanic resturants i have ever ate at. The carne asada is juciey and delicious and the queso fritos are too good to pass up.
author: Katrina V.

description: Winged lunch and this is where we ended up. Pretty good carne asada. Huge amounts of rice/plantains/fries. Unique drinks at the counter (very colorful). Not cheap for the lunch (~$13/person).
author: Thomas C.

description:
I go here strictly for the nacatamales. This is where my grandmother from Nicaragua would go to buy them as well when she got too old & tired to make them. So I can not review any other food but the tamales are the best ever!! My Dad & I actually did a SF mission day taste testing the nacatamales at the various restuarants & as soon as we walked in my dad went "this is the place that grandma Carmen used to take me".
Even so, we kept on with our taste testing mission through the mission district and every time, the tamales elsewhere did not match up to the quality/quantity for price and the flavor!!!
author: Christy M.

description:
As a Nicaraguan, I'll attest that this is the best place for the cuisine outside of Nicaragua. Very authentic and absolutely to die for. Fried cheese, carne asada, rice, and salad are fantastic,  and don't forget to try one of the traditional cold drinks like cacao (chocolate flavored) or cebada (sweet, thick, made from a grain). Get a bag of platanos (plantain chips) to go.

When any of my family comes into town, they refuse to leave without stopping here. We keep any leftovers for our next meal. This is how I introduced my husband to the cuisine and he fell in love. Enjoy!!!!
author: Anon A.

description:
Being half nicaraguan, im pretty picky about my food.  But here the food was delicious, tasty and not bad for the price.  I love the #1 El Antojeto (i think i misspelled that) with 2 types of meat, gallo pinto, salad, 2 type of plantains and fried cheese... so much food but oh so tasty.

Defiantly not for those watching their figure.
author: Emmy B.

description: Very good and large menu.  All the food is made to order.  They even had plantains, Micheladas and Margaritas.  Plus they have spicy chicken or tingas, most places don't have this dish.  Yumm
author: Dimitri M.

description:
Dear Antojitos Plate,

I know I just had you recently, last weekend in fact, but I miss you. 

I miss your delicious gallo pinto next to some tajadas fritas and queso frito topped with ensalada. I specially miss your succulent carne asada and chancho asado. 

I know I shouldn't say this, but you are the best I've ever had. Don't tell my family. They will be upset that I have been lying to them all these years telling them theirs is the best. I just didn't want to hurt their feelings. It's you that I love. 

I know I had to share you with the hubby and I'm sorry I didn't warn you about having a three way, but you are just too much for me. He enjoys you too, and he's Mexican. You have made us both fall in love with you and each and every time we come to you, you never disappoint. 

I'm so glad I had the chance to taste the cacao this time. It was great as was the flan, bunuelos, and cajeta de coco. Hope you'll allow them to be there again next time.

I would go back to see you in a heartbeat but you know our love can't happen everyday. Please take care of yourself Antojitos. I'll see you again soon and I'm sure you'll be just as good as I remember you. 

With love and affection,
Margo.
author: Margo G.

description:
MEAT AND POTATOES
More like Yucca and Plantain but you know what I mean. The meals are carbo heavy. Salad is just lettuce and a bit of tomato, and they also have cabbage salad. I need a little bit more fresh living veggies with my protein/carbos, that is the reason I only eat here once in a while.

EXPENSIVE
Another reason why I come here only once in a while. $15 dollars for lunch for one person, gratuity not included.  

INCONSISTENT
- Last time I was there the cabbage salad tasted like it was on the verge of decomposing.  I was expecting a nice fresh pickle like-salad.  "Picked" doesn't mean like the tomato should taste like it is about to go bad. 
- The red beans were way too salty. Almost unpleasantly salty. 
- White rice was mushy, not fluffy
- The salpicon was dry, and I mean dry. It has the consistency of shredded card board.  I had to generate a lot of saliva in order to swallow it.  

ON A POSITIVE NOTE
They have a nice selection of drinks that remind me of home - pozol, cacao and tamarindo (we also have those in Southern Mexico). Las Tinajas is all right, but it may not be for everyone. I had very bad meals there, but also good ones. Go and decide for yourself.
author: Raul A.

description:
I've never had Nicaraguan food before, so I cant really compare this dining experience with other Nicaraguan foods. 

This is a cafeteria style kind of restaurant so they have everything prepared in a steam table and is quickly served from it. I ordered the lunch special of the day which was the Tomato Steak and a side of fried cheese. (i yelped before going and everyone keeps talking about the fried cheese! i had to give in to peer pressure!) The lunch special comes with rice and a side of either beans or salad. 

I thought the steak was really tender and the tomato sauce was sweet and light. The steak felt a little over done though and I couldn't really tell whether it was steak or pork. I tried my co workers pork that came with his Antojitos plate and I think i liked that a lot more. Too bad the antojitos plate is HUGE. The cabbage salad that comes with it was good, a little different from what I'm used to, but definitely still enjoyable. 

The fried cheese. Man, it was good ...but very decadent. Really, really rich and a bit salty for m taste. I was only able to eat half of it. Imagine a panfried piece of really hard mozarella cheese. Its definitely soemtihgn you should try to understand. 

All of the portions are really big so definitely one plate can fill two people up and have just enough space for dessert. 

Everyone at our table had a sweet tooth so there were plenty of bunuelos and grilled(?) plantains to go around. Oh man, the bunuelos! I wish i didnt have so much of my main entree so I could have eaten more of the bunuelos! Also, something I don;t really know how to explain. It's kind of like thick sponge cake deep fried perfectly and then dipped in honey. Yes, basically a hard attack. I think its actually deep fried yucca and left in a cup of honey. Quick tip
: save the honey in the cup for dipping! 

The grilled (?) plantains were so delicious! I dont tihnk it was meant for a dessert dish, but it is so natrually sweet that you can just eat it for dessert. 

I really like this place for its homey feel, as if all of these dishes are things I would expect from a Nicaraguan grandmother. What was also awesome was that two of my co-workers are Nicaraguan, so they were able to give us a little history about each of the foods and how similar/different it would be if it was cooked at home. 

Mindy says: for now, its a 3.5 stars, but I could see myself coming here for some comfort food :D Bit on the pricey side though, esp for a spot in the mission. They take credit card (minimum $9) as well as cash. Also, hot sauces are really hot.
author: Mindy H.

description: Nicaraguan here, pretty good food, a bit pricey but pretty good. The arroz con camaron..really good, and the best nacatamales hands down.
author: Sonia C.

description:
Amazing steaks i love the way they marinated the carne asada bomb man! 

I do love their baho! Questions why nica americans put rice on their baho?
author: Don Y.

description:
This is the first time I've had Nicaraguan Food, so I have no context of comparison, but what I got was good.  It also helped that one of guys knew what to order.

I had a bowl of the Carne de Res (Beef soup with veggies) and split the Carne Asada.  The soup had a very simple flavor to it (add spices found on the table to give it kick), and the carne asada was seasoned perfectly.  It may not be the best cut of meat, but the way they marinate it sure does help.

For you SF Giants fans, you have to check out the back wall.  You will find the jerseys of Bernand (#7) and Livan Hernandez (#61) hanging on it.  Do you remember how big Hernandez got during his time with the Giants?  I'm thinking he may have visited Las Tinajas one too many times.  Or maybe he couldn't handle all the good eats of the City?

Anyways, yelp you later
author: Dan B.

description: Came here for my birthday, food is good, best one I have had so far. The prices are around 15/16 dollars a plate but the portions are big, so its worth it .The ladies that work there are nice. It's kind of cafeteria style by the way.
author: Iris M.

description: Yes pricey but so good! Sadly my mother was never taught how to cook her own peoples food- so when I'm craving my Nicoya fix, Las Tinajas is the place to go. I  order the vegetarian plate and I'm never dissapointed. I would recommend eating there because they give you more.
author: Stefanie T.

description:
Great food! They offer traditional and classic Nicaraguan favorites such as gallo pinto and maduro, which are palate-friendly even for the first-timer who has never tried Nicaraguan food before.

If you are in search of a low-calorie meal, this place is not for you. 

My only complaint is that this place was too crowded and cramped.
author: Sonya M.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! this is one of the best nicaraguence restuarants I have ever ate at before.  It's pretty much the only one I go to in SF.  The plates are a bit pricey BUT you get a good amount of food.  Everytime I go I usually share with my sister because they serve that much.  I always get the plato nica and it just tastes better every time.  Parking sucks but I always seem to find some type of parking a couple blocks away.  Although the last time I went the gallo pinto was a little burnt, but still tasted good.
author: Yvette I.

description: Way to pricey compare with other Nicaragua restaurants. Waitress are good with guesses but the people serving the food totally gives you attitude, specifically if you change ur mind or ask about the food ingredients.
author: G M.

description:
In my opinion the best nicaraguan restaraunt you'll find in san francisco!

I love that they always have the homemade juices, and especially my favorite cacao!! ask to get a little bit off ice though, so that you get more of the drink.

I'm nicaraguan myself, so im very picky and tend to compare everything to my mothers cooking, Even in my own family not many cook really good my mother is the main one everyone comes too, and for me to actually have an outside outlet, somewhere other than my mothers kitchen to go to to get comfort food, this would most def be it!  this restaraunt has been here since i was young since i can remember my father would call in orders to the owners and pick them up back in the day.

i always get the plato vegetariano, or salpicon, el maduro con crema, or bao! yummmm!! oh n the pastelitos are good! and carne asade, and everything is good, 

they do close early i think 4pm and at that time whatever main dish is usually already gone. so do come early, and they cook specific main dishes on specific days.

Overall: if you a first timer at trying nicaraguan food, do come here!! you'll enjoy the food, and become a nicaraguan food fan!!
author: Yaa Johanna M.

description:
Went here for lunch 'cuz I needed something new and I work in The Mission. It occurred to me that I had never sampled Nicaraguan fare. Thus, the stage was set.

First impression: if you have a decent command of Spanish and/or Latin culture you'll probably have a better experience here. The menu is in both Spanish and English, but the staff is more or less leaning in the Spanish direction.

I went for the daily special which was Carne de Res, rice and beans -- in MASSIVE portions. It was a little ridiculous. Three heaping mounds of these basic items just plopped onto my plate. Nothing else, but on the tables they give you a huge bucket of pickled onions and green salsa. I doused my food accordingly. I washed it all down with Orchata (note the lack of 'H' ... it's still rice milk).

The place was clean and not a taqueria by any standard. A little more upscale, with prices to match. Not fancy, mind you, but you're not gonna find a $3 burrito on the menu.
author: Wes T.

description: Over 20 years! I've been coming here since i was a teen and this place has always taken me back home at times when it was impossible to get anywhere near my country. I love everything here but to be hones sometimes i find that some of the dishes are a bit off for example the yucca might not be as tender as i would like it or the meat in the Baho is a little too dry but for the most part the vigoron, nacatamales, gallo pinto, lengua, los bunuellos, la cosa de orno, los pastelitos, sopa borracha, la carne asada is all off the chain. If you don't know what most of this things are just ask the ladies behind the counter and they will explain each and every one of them to you. By the way these ladies have been here since the start most of them being family.
author: Seb M.

description: Been coming here ever since I was a baby! Great food, great atmosphere, great service. Love the Monday special and admiring the odd paintings. Always make a point to come back here when visiting home..
author: Montserrat S.

description: I've grown up eating Las Tinajas. This is my families "go to" for Nicaraguan food.  My parents lived in the Mission so they went here a lot.  Now, I'm in San Jose and they are in Union City and we all still drive up to the city just for their food.  The food is great and the family that runs it is awesome.  One of my favs!
author: Evelyn R.

description: Best Nica food around! Only bummer is all the weird hours and closures. We went yesterday after driving for a long time only to find they were closed:/ needless to say this isn't the first time I've done this so for future trips, I will call ahead:) The gallo pinto and fried cheese is just like my family makes it and I'm 100% Nicaraguan. Sadly only giving 4 stars because of the inconvenience in the hours and days it's closed.
author: Jen A.

description:
I have read the reviews about this great Nicaraguan business located in the heart of the Mission District, and I do have to say for the most part the reviews have been spot on.  As far as the choices for Nicaraguan cuisine in the San Francisco Bay Area, the two major hotspots are the " original " Mission District-based Nicaraguan restaurant " El Nicaragua " which is located just a little further down the street from Las Tinajas, and as far as authentic Nicaraguan food goes I have to say El Nicaragua is a tad more consistent in it's actual " Nicaraguan " flavor, although Las Tinajas is a tad more tastier.  Let me illustrate to you the obvious examples, solely based on the cuisine:

     The first and most obvious point of contention between this restaurant and " El Nicaragua " is that the couple who owns this restaurant are Chinese Nicaraguans, and yes THERE ARE MANY ASIAN Nicaraguans, as well as Arab, Jew, German, French, Spanish, and other peoples from many parts of the world who settled in Nicaragua and somehow managed to arrive here.  The little I know about the couple is that they fled during the Sandinista Revolution, most likely to escape political persecution at the hands of the new Marxist regime.  Being that they are Chinese Nicaraguans, it is not surprising that some of the aspects of Chinese cooking is reflected in the way they cook their own brand of Nicaraguan food, particularly the GARLIC they seem to oversaturate their food with, which is not a standard ingredient that is used overabundantly in Nicaraguan food " back home " but we are here in the States and cos of the lack of Nicaraguan restaurants in the Bay Area who can complain?  This restaurant is as close to " authentic " Nicaraguan food as possible, the national drinks such as the pitaya, cacao, tiste, chicha and others is a tad oversweetened, the gallo pinto is good to excellent although I am not quite sure if they use the standard Nicaraguan red beans or pinto beans which Mexicans prefer... the last time I was there ( exactly one month ago ) my plate of Antojitos Las Tinajas was of the same consistent quality I have expected from my food at this restaurant all the years I have been going there, although the carne asada was a bit tough and ultimately very hard to swallow, literally!  The rest of the food was good, and since I rarely order anything but Antojitos I really can't say much about anything else on their menu, although my brother loves their lengua, which is all he eats anyway.  If you want a TRULY AUTHENTIC Churrasco estilo Nica then you will most likely have to fly to one of the Somoza-owned " Los Ranchos " restaurants that are in Miami, otherwise this is as good as it gets if you're don't want to spend 13 hours on a plane to Managua.  Thumbs Up, and I hope the quality of the food here stays consistent for a long time to come.
author: Gonzalo O.

description: A friend told me to come here for real Nicaraguan food, but I never found the time to try it out.  I finally made it. HOLLAR! She told me to order "A typical dish" and I loved it!  The pork was amazing, fried banana was awesome, and there were too many banana chips to finish. The salad and rice was pretty damn good too, but I may be bias since I have a love affair for veggies and carbs.  And the most amazing drink was the cacao! YUMMMMM. I was downing that like I was breathing.  Hahaha.  I tried fried cheese for the first time and I'm not a huge fan.  It was too rich for me, but I would be up to give it another try.
author: Amy L.

description: Food is good but it could be better. I ordered salpicon and it was very dry. I have had better elsewhere.  I thought the plate came with queso frito and they wanted to charge $2.50 for it? Umm no thank you. People are nice and friendly but would rather get a complete meal rather than being up charged for everything.  I always try to give this place a chance but its way too expensive.
author: Christina R.

description: Love queso frito, platano frito, casamiento (gallo pinto)...... everything here is really good! The only thing that sucks here are they're hours... sometimes they're opened sometimes they're closed. Other than that it's really good!
author: Irma R.

description:
Today I ordered the typical dish or 'el plato tipico', because it's one of my favorites. It's a combination plate with large portions of pork, banana chips, 'gallo pinto', salad, and fried cheese.
Yummy, yummy, yummy. I haven't been here for 2 years and they haven't missed a step. It's the reason why they are the #1 Nicaragua restaurant ... hands down!

As a Mission District native, I love all types of Latino food. At the top of my list is 'nica' food - and I always take the opportunity to ask a 'nicoya' what their #1 restaurant is...and they always say this one! :)

However, I did not order the 'cacao' because my plate was over $15 with tax..... But I strongly recommend this chocolaty drink, it's very mouth-watering.

The negative side.... there has to be one, of course?
* hours: very minimal, see below
* waitress a little snooty or bad attitude.
* 25 cents for extra tortillas, only comes in 3 small ones.
* must leave a waitress tip, since they bring you to a table.
* $13.50 for this combination plate. Kinda pricey but you get lots of food. I had my 2 pieces of pork 'to go'....
author: mario c.

description: My first experience with Nicaragua food.  It was wonderful.  I ordered a combination plate of beef, pork, rice and beans, plantains, fried cheese and salad.  It was very good.  The service was nice, the staff was nice, the place was clean and easy to find.  I would go back.
author: Matthew B.

description:
It was all good!! My Sweetie took me here on V~Day. The only time I've had Nicaraquan food was when my mom and grandmother would make it. It was very good(the resturant). Some of the food items were very familar, which I havent eaten in a long while. But it wasnt like mom's cookin. 

The portions were very "Alot of Food" and the price was okay. The style of the establishment was like catatria style. I will have to say that I would go back. I might have to bring my mother and hear what she might have to say about their "Nicaraqua Food".
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Overall the food at Las Tinajas is pretty decent.  I've been coming here for YEARS and I've found that the food is hit or miss.  The lengua can sometimes be too tough (personally I think when my mom cooks lengua it melts in my mouth).  The portions are huge...Usually I'll order the Typical Nicaraguan plate with gallo pinto, platanos maduros, ensalade de repollo y queso frito.  

But lengua aside, I love coming to Las TInajas to get a bit of my country's food...I'll just leave the cooking of lengua to mom.  Everything else is worth trying...oh and the typical beverages like cacao are delish...yumm!!!

*******UPDATE******
Food here is declining rapidly!! Had the Tripe soup the other day and MAN did the hand slip when they were adding the salt??  The fried bananas were tough and not soft at all!! Pretty disappointing and the service...well, specifically, one of the ladies that works the dining room (she looks like a man) and picks up the dishes is insulting and rude and has been to 3 out of my 4 family members.  We did complain on our last visit the other day and informed the owners about our horrible experience with that woman and vowed to never come back.  Overall, Las Tinajas is not what it used to be, coming from a Nicaraguan BORN in Nicaragua...however I don't know where else I can find Nicaraguan food other than my own kitchen (but mom rarely cooks those authentic dishes) so do I shell out $15 a plate for authenticty (if that) or do I wait for MOM??  I think I'd rather wait!!!
author: Karen B.

description:
So i just had tinajas today w mom and my uncle who have been coming here for the past decade.  Its annoying bc they are only open during the day, and only on weekdays so u really just have to have the day off of work or work in SF mission and be able to hit this place up for lunch.  By 4pm u can't eat in and its to go only. 
i know this bc i almost suffered through thousands of accidents having my mother rush to make it on time (we live in san mateo now)..or forgetting its the weekend and only realising it bc we fancied some caldo de res and its FREAKIN CLOSED!!! bullocks i tell you.

any how today, monday special- lengua w salsa, i got the lomo de res and the yucca chips w the fried piece of cheese. all delicious. and authentic.

VERY AUTHENTIC. this is nicaraguan home cooking down to the desserts which i love the (oh snap i forgot what it was called) i think its the Pio Quinto (nicaraguans reading this please dont kill me if i f-ed it up) ne way its rum cake with custurd..superb, and the tres leches cake is pretty ace too. 
the place is always packed and the servings are MASSIVE. forreals you get your money's worth, the plates are like a massive mountain.  3 heaping spoonful of gallo pinto looked like 3 cups and half a chicken for 8 bucks.  deal.

AND they have all the nicaraguan drinks...cacao, chicha, cebada, granadia, tamarindo, and the purple stuff w lil black seeds in it...name starts w a P....not pinolio  (oh man i suck at this)  

ne way if u have no job during the day, day off from work or live on the mission, and are not on some stupid carb free, fat free, ca ca diet. def give this place the green light

p.s. flor de cana not avail here..i asked
author: Paola L.

description:
I love this place.  I am Nicaraguan and feel that the food is authentic.  To me, it tastes just like homemade cooking.  Yes, I've had better homemade Nicaraguan food---but hey if you're looking for a Nicaraguan restaurant then you can't be picky because there are not many!  My family has also ordered large quantities of food for parties and such.

The format of the place is somewhat like a "cafeteria".  You get in a line with a tray and place an order, which is either filled immediately if it is a basic item such as the plato nica especial or you receive a number if they need to cook it special (i.e. carne asada).    I think the pricing is all relative because I would not call this place "expensive" since most plates are within 10 -15 bucks.   The food is tasty and the servings are generous.  I suppose it is "expensive" within Mission District standards, but the place is basically a monopoly on good authentic Nicaraguan food in the city.  It's not like taquerias, which you can find on every corner and therefore the pricing is cheaper due to heightened competition.

You move down the line to get drinks and desserts.   The drinks are an assortment of Nicaraguan beverages.  Try the cacao --- its Nicaraguan chocolate milk and its great.   It is made fresh from the cacao beans, which is why you will see the little pile of grinds at the bottom of you cup when you finish.

Some folks are turned off by the cafeteria style routine, but I love it because you get your food quickly.  No waiting, unless you order carne asada (which comes pretty quickly).  The ladies that work here are friendly and those that clean the dining area are attentive.  I have no complaints here.
author: Adie X.

description: Love this place, it is too bad that they only open until 2pm and close on Sunday and Monday!!!  Their food is delicious, and they used to give a lot of food, but now the prices are high and smaller portions it is still DELICIOUS!!!!
author: E M.

description: My gf took me in for the first time ever and I already tried Nicaraguan  food but she told me this was the restaurant to eat if I want real Nicaraguan  food. So I tried it and I loved it.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Best Nicoya spot! 

This is definitely my first choice on Nicoya restaurants, when I go here I always get the mixed plate that bring chancho, carne asada, gallo pinto, tajada, queso frito..... You will for sure have to take about half home since its a pretty big plate!. 

Their cacao is the bomb!
author: Diana M.

description:
After watching Anthony Bourdain in Nicaragua, my husband and I were tempted to try Nicaraguan food. We checked several places on Yelp, but ultimately decided on Las Tinajas.  
We tried a variety of food-some meat dishes, gallo pinto and the vegetarian plate. We got the nacatamale to-go.  I also tried the cacao. Everything on my vegetarian plate was tasty and fresh.  My husband enjoyed all of his food as well.  The servings are fairly large and filling so we had a lot of leftovers.  
The restaurant is clean and the employees are friendly.  I would warn folks that this place closes at 4:30 pm.  We arrived around 4:10 pm and the sign was already flipped to closed.....after an hour and a half on the road to get there.  Thankfully they were still serving food and they allowed us to dine-in.  Several others that arrived after us were required to order to-go.
Overall, good food and a nice experience.  I would recommend giving this place a try.
author: Heidi T.

description:
Tuesday and Friday is Bajo day - for those counting calories without losing the flavor this is the place to be.

LOVE IT, but not crazy about the prices
author: Claudia J.

description: My favorite nicaraguan restaurant. Menu changes everyday, the portions are generous and it tastes amazing. Great place for a homemade lunch.
author: Elsa L.

description:
Las Tinajas rocks the bells!

This place is a Nicaruaguan restaruant that serves homestyle food for the masses.  I was introduced to the place back in the late 90's by  friend whose whole family makes the trip over from the East Bay once a month to get a taste of homestyle Nicauraguan food.  According to Sheila, every Nicaruagan family from Redding to Salinas makes the pilgramage here on a regular basis.

With the steam table in the front and cloth on the table, it doesn't look like most of the other joints in the hood.  But it is packed all day with extended families getting their grub on, and nary a Mission hipster in sight.

The carne asada is the best in the city.  Get the combo plate that comes with asada, pork and fried cheese.  Slather it with the chimchurri like sauce and chow down.  If you are feeling adventurous get one of the daily specials on the steam table, like the tongue stew. The portions are gargantuan, and the owners are friendly (Chinese by way of Nicuragua).  The only drawback is the hours, they close at 5pm every day and are closed Sunday.
author: evan J.

description:
I have been going to this restaurant for so many years is crazy, I used to go there all the time when I lived on the Mission, now I live in Antioch and go there whenever I'm in San Francisco.
The food is great, the carne asada is to die for as well as the vegetarian dish (rice, plantain and fried cheese)for my wife, I had the sopa de res (ox tail soup) several times and I always get los bun~uelos, picos and specially cacao 2 big orders, usually I drink one on my way back home.
I dont give this place 5 stars just because it closes at 5 p.m. and is not open on Sundays (what's up with that)
author: Rich M.

description: I have not been there in a while, and last time I was there I thought the prices were, well....pricey. Today was a disappointment, I ordered the plato Nica $18.00 with a cacao drink. PLATO NICA: rice and beans-fried plantains-crunchy plantains-fried cheese-salad-pork. The rice and beans were average, sweet fried plantains, they only gave me 2 pieces, and they looked like they have been chewed. The pork was hard and tough, the crunchy plantains hard and old. I lived a block from this place years back and the quality was all there, I see the same owners, but perhaps the cooks aren't the same.
author: S F.

description: One consequence of eating here was my stomach felt terrible and I didn't feel well at all, the rice was quite tasteless and greasy and the meat was nothing special it was just meet tasting and not in a good way I ended up giving my rice beans and meet to the friendly but zany homeless guy and told him to just share with any and all of the buddies he wanted to who decided to join me for a late lunch, who is nice enough but, the stories he told, well... They were just a little bit more than just a little bit out there and thankfully he came with me , he spoke Spanish, because it ended up that half the people in this restaurant workers, cannot speak English well and all, and this guy did most of the speaking I think it was something like almost $$20 per person which is quite a lot of money for such a low quality, and as a lot of people have mentioned it's not a fancy restaurant with waiters and people that tend to their customers but rather more in the cafeteria kind of style, so would I come back? I guess if I was absolutely starving and there was nothing else to eat then maybe? But probably not even then I ate just a little bit, I could not really finish my meal very well at all
author: Rachel N.

description:
Authentic Nicaraguan Food..that's what it says on the menu.  I am not Nicaraguan so I have no idea how "authentic" it is.  Our loud speaking Nicaraguan worker always speak volumes of this place...and after a few times getting stuff to go from this place....i must say this place is yummy for my tummy.  Authentic or not....i'm sold on this place!  My favorite plate is their Carne de Res Con Vegetales...aka.....BEEF STEW!!!

Mixed with baby vegetables, rice, beans, tortilla and their special vinegary dipped onions (crunchy and spicy)......and you have yourself a party in your belly.  Damn...i really really enjoy the onions....add that stuff on some burgers.....tasted excellent.

Also try their Bistec Entomatado if you get a chance....or if you are adventurous....go for their killer combo plates.  Lets just say they throw in everything on their menu in there. =)
author: Dave L.

description:
This is the Nicaraguan restaurant that pierced my virginity into Nica fare.  I'm a huge fan of plates, and even bigger fan of meat plates.  This place, when given the right amount of time to prepare can set you up for lunch and dinner.  Trust me, you won't have to eat until the next day.  Plantains that stick to your ribs and meats that are tender and juicy is right for that carnivore in you.  My girlfriend has been coming here for years with her family (whose family is from Nica) and have shared many plates, burbs, and probably antacid pills.  
Eat this food, make your belly full!
author: felix c.

description:
Have you ever found yourself in the City By The Bay and wondered "Is there such a thing as spanish speaking asians?" on top of "Where can one feed a cow size hunger?" Well today is your lucky day cause I know a place where you can kill 2 birds with one stone!

La Tinajas in the Mission is just the place you are looking for. This Nicaraguan joint is run by a Chinese speaking couple it it fuckin holds it DOWN! Youd think they have a cattle ranch out back judging from the amount of carne asada being ordered and the massive portions they hook you up with. Bistro introduced me to this spot a few years back and it has become one of my favorite joints in the City. I usually oreder the Carne Asada Estilo Nica. Med rare. The plate comes with a heart helping of beans and rice, fried bananas, a carmelized banana and a salad, which on this trip i was not hooked up with, but no matter cause i couldnt finish the damn thing. Bistro odered something similar but it came mixed with pork and beef and the same fixens. He got his salad. Bastards.
author: Danny E.

description:
I have not been here in a while but the food was fantastic.  One of my co-workers who is Nicoya would bring me here when ever she had the craving for some authentic Nicaraguan food.  Unfortunately she left the company and I have not been there since.    We have never dinned in this establishment it has always been "to go."  This place gets crowded and lines are just to long.  If you only have 1hr for lunch you will not make it back to work.  So you might as well have your lunch to go.  Prices are expensive but the plates say it all.  The portions they give you can feed two people. 

I would always ordered the Bistec Ensebollado.  One huge cut of rib eye, side of steak fries, salad and caramelized onions.  The steak is always juicy and flavorful.  Caramelized onions sweet and delicious.  The fries golden and tender, not greasy at all.  You will also enjoy the gallo pinto or some places call it casamiento.  Perfect ratio of beans to rice and cooked perfectly.  

As mentioned before in other reviews this place does close early hours are from 8-16:30 Tuesday-Saturday.  I just don't understand why they close so early.  Most people get off of work at 17:00 and by this time its to late to enjoy some filling Nicoya food. -1 star for closing early.
author: David P.

description:
Arroz con camarones was delicious. Lots of big juicy shrimp, with fluffy rice, served alongside fried plantains. Great combo of sweet, sour, spicy, and savory. Plus, HUGE portions.

The stuff you get off the line didn't look very good. My mom got some stewed beef that was really tender, but lacking in flavor. It also left a funny taste in my mouth after trying some.

Would come back - menu sounds very interesting.
author: Jimmy C.

description: What's up with this place? I had it recommended recently by a Nicaraguan friend and it never seems to be open... Are they on vacation, or closed permanently, or do they just keep wonky hours?
author: Aimee G.

description: So, today I was happily re-aquainted with an old favorite. I had not been to this restaurant in about 4 years (mostly because I live in Campbell), today though we decided to make the drive up and re-visit this place. The food was as amazing as I remember it! I enjoyed every last bite! And Yes while it is a bit on the expensive side, I've eaten at more expensive restaurants that didn't give the portions Las Tinajas does. The service is amazing. I can't wait to go back and have another carne asada plate!
author: Becky B.

description: If you haven't tried Nicaraguan food, this is the place to go!! They have goo Nicaraguan food here starting from the gallo pinto& platanos frito.. MMMMMMmmmm..
