The only thing here is that the food is somewhat pricy which I find to be ridiculous because c'mon for a plate of rice & beans with steak theyre going to charge about $20. Yea rather cook at home! But if your in the mood for some quick already made Nicoya food then come here! its good, pricy, but GOOD!
author: J V.

description: My family drives all the way from SJ just to come eat lunch here. The Carne Asada with gallo pinto and platain chips are so good. They come in Big propotions.  My favorite is the fried cheese. The couple in the front are always very sweet to us. Best Nicoya food around.
author: Ricky P.

description: In the area to snap pics of a nearby church, stopped in here as another place where I wanted to eat lunch was closed. The routine is to grab a tray, order from the cafeteria-style line, and get a number. Get seated and the waitresses bring you your food when it's ready!! While waiting to order, I saw this plate packed to the sky with meat and rice and asked another person what it might be as the server behind the counter wasn't there. It was "Churrasco Nica" ($18) which is served with fileted tenderloin marinated with parsley and olive oil, and comes with steak fries. I asked for that and got a passionfruit drink (tasty) and waited not more than a few minutes when it was served. The place was packed when I entered and thought this must be a sight: an asian who speaks (and ordered in) spanish in a Nica place. The food was tasty with good flavor (me likes dat), the drink was good and I truly totally enjoyed my meal. Though it's a bit pricey, I wouldn't mind stopping back in here when in the area. I also tasted a rice custard and while I like/love egg custard, don't like any other type of custard. It was quite good with a bit of cinnamon on top. The place was very clean and the women worked quickly to clear and clean the tables. I've found another place to speak spanish!! Street parking only but by a milagro parked right in front!!
author: Tony L.

description: I am NIcaraguan and have been to all of the Nicaraguan restaurants in the area. This is the best. You name it, nacatamales, lengua, chancho frito, gallo pinto, ect, ect,..... Yes, it's the best. All you need to do is to survey who is in there eating. Mostly all latinos who know, and those who are not and know great food. It is a restaurant that has it all, not only entrees, but also Nicaraguan beverages and desserts.
author: Evaristo V.

description:
not bad at all. 

one of my warehouse guys is nicaraguan. he says i should try this place out. so today, whens he going off to lunch i ask him to bring me a togo box. i got the thursday pork ribs special. pretty damn good i must admit. some pieces were tougher then others, some were fattier, but really, nothing to complain about. it was a stew type deal with baby corn and baby carrots, each cooked pretty damn well. the meal came with the usual staples, rice, beans, tortilla..... but what took me by surprize was this onion thing..... yes onions for you mutha fuckers that caught that thread yesterday and this morning..... hahaha go figure.  its a pickled onion thats tart and spicy. it cuts through the meat and rice like.... well kimchee does with korean food..... yeah yeah koreans and their kimchee right? 

this pickled onion is a must.
author: Euge L.

description:
What the hell is ACHIOTE?  yeah if you don't know what ths is you have not had Nicaraguan food.  SO YOU MUST GO HERE!!!!!!!!!!! The only nicaraguan food better than this place is the nica food my mom makes.  
So back to Achiote, you might know it as anise seed.  Mix achiote with cumino (cumin) and you have the best dressing for a side of beef.  And boy is it some good steak.  
I will warn you in advance, the portions are huge, and you will drop $50.00 on lunch for three, but it is money well spent.  (I recommend you bring an appetite, and para los verdadero nicoyas, bring your own tupperware;))
If this is your first time trying Nicaraguan food be sure and try the plato typico.  This platter combines some classic food items, such as platanos fritos (maduro, and not so maduro.)  You will also enjoy the gallo pinto (rice and beans) made with frijoles de seda (these are not plain ole' pinto beans, these shits are imported.)  
Be sure to try some of the funky colored drinks.  I recommend Pinole (it is like horchata, but is corn/cacoa based, ) or my personla favorite, sebada (pink barley based goodness.)
At this point if you are still hungry have some dessert.  Maybe some rice pudding, I don't know.
What are you doing still reading this?  get your @ss down to the mission and check this place out!!!
author: international super bert a.

description: Someone brought me to-go, not sure what exactly what the dishes' names were, but one was pork and the other was beef.  They were both yummy!  The meet wasn't dry and the marinade they used was so good that I licked my fork after I finished.  I haven't had the time to go eat there; but i definitely plan on going there the next time I'm around Mission.
author: Tadaa T.

description: I will keep this short but sweet:  I come from the land down under (no, not "that" land -- Argentina), so by default I am automatically entitled to be a (self-proclaimed) beef critic/connoisseur.  When my MexiNicoya friend brought me here, I had my reservations, but let's just say I was already mentally planning a weekend lunch here with the parentals, halfway through my Churrasco Nica.  This Argentine offically approves the churrascos at Las Tinajas.  Thank you.
author: Valeria D.

description:
By Far the Best Nicaraguan Food in the whole Northern California.......
my only problem with this place is the hours they are open.....they don't stay open very late......
author: W P.

description: it's been a while sicne i've been here, does anyone know what cut of beef they use for the carne asada? i want to try and copy it so i don't have to make the drive. this is the place to try out Nicaraguense food.
author: Jose E.

description: The most authentic Nicaraguan food in San Francisco.  The food is amazing.  They have a different menu for every day of the week plus the usual popular platters.  The portions are very large (I always have to split with a friend).  I have been going to this restaurant with my family since I was a child so it is very dear to my heart.
author: Kattya B.

description: Try it! You will not be disappointed, I recommend getting the antojito platter. It comes with some of the best Nicaraguan food, all on one plate.
author: H. T.

description: Gallo Pinto, Platanos, Ensalada de Repollo, Queso Fritto, Cebada, and Sopa Borracha this is what I call a meal and las tinajas is my go to place for Nicaraguan food in this city! Growing up this place was my family's mecca when it came to getting authentic dishes. Las Tinajas may be a turn-off with its cafeteria like setting but believe me the food is great!!!
author: Paola W.

description: If you like Latin American food and want to try something new, Las Tinajas is the way to go. Nicaraguan food has many of the familiar flavors of Central America but it is a cuisine all to itself. Everything on their menu is very good, so don't be intimidated by not knowing what the names on the menu mean. The only issue with this place are the hours (otherwise it would get 5 stars). You pretty much have to go there for lunch during the week or maybe an early dinner on Saturday. I'd go right now but it's closed!
author: Ryan S.

description:
been going here for a couple of years. always enjoyed it but it is going down hill. 
went there saturday and noticed the price has gone up AGAIN. we are talking plates of mostly beans and rice - at almost 20 a plate. 
i ordered a gallon of cacao to bring home - paid 17. got home - oakland- to find i have horchata! what the hell! 
also the dining room was almost empty. it has always been jammed packed. maybe the owners should realize with unemployment at an all time high, and other decent eateries, crappy parking, and bankers hours, they may have out priced themselves 
i'm going to try other nica places
author: mabel w.

description:
best Nicaraguan food i've ever had in the United States.

the soup is just like my mama makes. the gallo pinto could have been better, but the verdes and pork and carne asada was top-notch.

highly recommended.
author: Ronny K.

description: This is the best Nicaraguan Fritanga in the bay area !  The hours really suck though -   I think they cater to the local businesses in the area. Otherwise I would give them five stars. I usually get the Vegetarian plate which is Gallo, tajadas, salad, and I add maduros too! But they have good size portions and two people can eat from most of the plates.  If you are craving Nica food this is the place to go!
author: Ara M.

description:
best nicaraguense food to date!!

i go there with my girlfriends and it is simply the best nicarguense food we have ever had!
author: Carolina M.

description: Food was tasty but some of the items were a bit pricey for the Mission District.
author: Jay S.

description: I just had to write a review to sort of balance out any of the previous bad reviews i've read here.  I work in the Mission on Mission Street and I've been coming to Las Tinajas since it opened.  The food is served sort of "cafeteria line" and you take the food and drink on a tray to your table. The tables have table cloths, very nice...Nicaraguan artwork displayed on the walls, and there's a roving waitress to help out in the dining area.  Now, to the food.  I like it all, but I especially recommend the bajo which is not available everyday so don't be afraid to call and ask first.  Otherwize, order the daily special and you'll be ok.
author: Jerome W.

description: There are large portions in this world and then there is Las Tinajas!  I had the steak with onions, rice beans and plantains included, and it was savory.  The steak was not a fillet mignon but they season and cook it perfectly.  The onions were caramelized and the plantains were sweet like candy.  The reason I subtracted the one star was because of the prices, if I am ordering cafeteria style and drinking my coke from a can the prices should be lower.  I can't wait to eat my leftovers.
author: Michael M.

description: I love Las Tinajas! I have been going there for many years... The thing that really sucks are the hours. By the time I get there, they're usually closed and it makes me soooo sad because I really love the food. They give you huge portions and its just so delicious! Oh, how I love Nicaraguense food! ... Especially at Las Tinajas! =0)
author: Aurita U.

description: I've only ever had take out from here, and its been consistently good.  Always have the carne asada, rice, beans, plantains plate.  Around $15 a plate.  Pretty steep for what it is, but one plate could easily feed two people and the taste is on point.  Don't think I've ever had beans that taste as good as Las Tinajas's, for whatever that's worth.  Bean lovers rejoice!  Right across from Cha Cha Cha.  Now you know where it is right?
author: Barry A.

description: Good food. Huge portions but way too expensive.  The food they sell isn't pricey to make. I wish they'd open later in the day as well as Sundays!
author: Claudia L.

description: I didn't rate 5 stars because it is expensive and because I agree with Karen B. this place can be a hit or miss. However, it's the best Nicaraguan food in San Francisco. I'm going there today for lunch, can't wait to have the plato vegetariano and atolillo!
author: Anabelle B.

description:
There are a handful of Nicaraguan restaurants in the Bay Area and Las Tinajas is the best.  It has been a staple in the Mission for a couple of decades.  

When the food is good, it's GOOD!  The portions are large and flavorful!  Their steaks are heavenly and the prices are cheap (compared to other neighborhoods).  Tip: try the 'leche de cacao' 

The crappy stuff :  long lines, open till 4, closed Sundays & Mondays, food is hit or miss (if it has been sitting for a while)...hence the four stars - the price of being popular.
author: Roger M.

description: Food is pretty good, although my mom makes better nicaraguan food ;) A litthe over-priced for the location, etc, although they do serve you a lot of food. It sucks that they don't open until late..  Staff is friendly and nice!
author: Reyna S.

description: This is my FAVORITE restaurant! I've been coming here scine I was a child, probably scine I was a baby considering my parents love this place so much that they hired Las Tinajas to cater their wedding. I'm vegetarian but I'm always dipping my tortilla or rice into the sauces served on the meat plates. The desserts are yum, my fav is the borachito and my fav drink is cacao. MMMMMmmmmmm my mouth is watering just thinking about the food. Although a bit greasy, I love everything about this place :)
author: Yessenia M.

description: I would die if i couldn't get gallo pinto and tajadas and cebollita encurtido and quesito fresco and buuelos. I simply would die!
author: Andrea R.

description: Excellent, authentic Nicaraguan food! I had the fried plantains, red beans. The salad was not that great, but the other food more than made up for the weak salad. I had a delicious beverage (forgot the name of it) with rice, milk, and cinnamon. Very refreshing, and I'll have to have it again! The cheese (queso) is very tasty fried or raw. The only downside is that I couldn't understand the people behind the counter, but I am a very adventurous eater!
author: Lara K.

description: Being from Nicaragua and now living in the East Bay I grew up eating Nica food everyday.  The food here is as close to my mama's that I have to get my fix every month.  El plato tipico is my favorite and will last me a few days or I can share it with my daughter because it is huge. I usually order extra queso frito y maduro frito because those are my comfort foods.
author: El L.

description: not as delicious as homemade cooking but VERY VERY close. love this place.
author: Lady B.

description: Las Tinajas is the bomb--literally.  I am a big eater, and can usually finish what's on my plate, but the last time I was there--for lunch on a Saturday--I ordered the bajo stew and finished about half of it.  I could barely finishthe leftovers for dinner.  It was the kind of heavy, starchy food that puts one into a stupor after eating.  This may sound bad to some people, but sometimes, that's what you need.  I'd never had Nicaraguan food before but some friends really like the soup and so I went up to Las Tinajas for lunch.  The prices aren't super cheap, should they really be for the quality and portion size at Las Tinajas?  I really like the cafeteria-style dining with so many delicious choices (gallo pinto, queso frito, cabbage salad, platanos...), and the juices are really good too.  The people who work there are very kind as well and I appreciate it that they spoke to me in Spanish even though I'm fairly obviously a gringo (who speaks pretty good Spanish, though).  The downside is that Las Tinajas is only open for lunch and is closed on Sunday, and because I live and work in the East Bay, it only leaves me one day in the week to get my fix.  I definitely plan my trips to SF on Saturdays now to include a stop for some Las Tinajas.
author: Reed A.

description: This place sucks !!! People are not friendly. When i was still working on my plate, the waitress have been standing next to me for a couple of minutes and asked me, Whether i want to box my food....?!!! I felt that was so rude.....But Didnt have any option of saying other than YES, and know what..? After i reached my place and opened the box...there you go....The fried plaintains are missing !!!  I did have couple of fried plaintains on my plate when she took the plate inside to pack...They dont bring the box to your table..rather She took my food plate inside and brought the packed box on my table...I even tipped her!!!! Sheesh.....Why dont people be little decent?! We are paying huge bucks for the food and C'mon this is something that I dont take it easy....I wouldnt go back to this place ever again...!!! This place might be apt for Big eaters  who cares only the quantity of food...but not the other qualities...Man, They dont even smile !!! A big NO NO to this place....!!!!!

author: Kali K.

description: Being a fellow Nica, I was reluctant to find anything as good as my mom's cooking but this place does a good job.  The plates are enormous so be very hungry when you go.  For the only Nicaraguan restaurant in the bay that I know of, they hold it down.  it's almost worth the drive from San Jose.  The hours suck though so you have to try to make it before they close and good luck going if it's packed because table seating fills up quick.  The only thing I don't like is the tres leches which is too sweet and too fluffy.  Besides that, enjoy!
author: Veronica C.
